reviewText:
Apparently all positive reviews for this game are 'joke' reviews.

This isn't!

For $2 you get a puzzle game with a distinctive art style, kooky music and disturbing capital punishment gameplay mechanic.

Each level consists of listening to 4 clues provided by an eye-witness (to a crime? It is unclear) which range from the lucid ('I'm positive he was tall') to the bizarre ('I think he was not a baby man'). There's a game-logic here that revolves around language rules and motifs that are coherent only within the game world. Once you've started to fathom the meaning of 'tiny' and 'chunky', 'odd' and 'manly' you progress further into the game. As you do the descriptions become increasingly unreliable, the lineup becomes obscured, you are given limited time and you end up battling yourself as much as anything.

The game uses the same sort of puzzle logic as a cryptic crossoword, and once you are tuned in to its rules and systems it all makes a lot of sense.

My only criticism is that I'd like to be able to quit a bad run (say I've accidentally clicked 'release' on the wrong person). But then there's something really quite sad and thought-provoking about watching someone you know is innocent going to the chair. I feel like the governor of Texas or something.

This isn't going to last you 60 hours, but it will comfortably occupy a weekend. At this price point, I cannot not recommend play thingy.

reviewText:
A lot more fun than I expected!

I heard the echo bouncing off the walls of the Steam community that one of my favourite game developers, Edmund Mcmillen, had released a new game on Steam. Of course, I had to take a gander.
I knew that Edmund had been working on several things, including The Binding of Isaac Rebirth and Mewgenics (which I can’t wait for!) so I was a little surprised to hear that something completely random (or at least to me) had come out of the woodwork.

Looking at the trailer and the price, I kind of had the impression that this would be a “mini-game” type of thing that I would likely play for five minutes and never touch again. A little, but not entirely, like the little games that were in “The Basement Collection” also by Edmund.

To my surprise this game was actually more addictive than I thought it would be.
The foundation of this game being that you’re given a line-up of suspects and a witness that will give you four hints as to who the criminal is. You have to narrow down the suspects and “point the finger” at which you think is guilty. This results in that suspect being executed and if you’re right, you move onto the next case. The aim of the game assumingly being to get as far as you can without murdering someone innocent.

Seeing as I thought I would barely spend 8 minutes on this game, so far I’m 8 hours in and 88% complete with the game. I have technically “finished” the game, but I’m going to try and 100% it. Most of the achievements being mile stones in how far you get or for executing special characters that come up in the line ups.

The mechanics of this game is quite easy to figure out after a while and you will really pick up a knack for finding what you are looking for. 8 hours in and I already feel like a pro! (How sad)

Edmund’s usual art style which I know I love is used in this game and that always makes the games he released all the better to me.

All in all I think it’s a pretty alright game. If I wasn’t such a big Edmund fan I honestly doubt if I would have bought it, but in my opinion it isn’t too bad of a game for the price. It’s something small to sink into when you can’t really be bothered for the big, engrossing and time consuming games.

UPDATE: At 10 hours in I managed to 100% the game. The last two achievements I needed were for beating the game without the automatic second chance you get when failing once, and executing one of the special characters that randomly come up in the line ups. I was expecting the achievement for beating the game without the continue to be a lot more tedious then it was. In honesty, once you learn the characteristics well enough it’s not too bad finishing without fail. However, I think most of those additional hours was spent on me trying to get the special character I needed to appear.

I also decided to read through other reviews for this game, of which a lot that I read seemed to have been negative. Most of the negativity seemed to surround the clues and how “vague” they are. I would just say that you just need to keep in mind that each clue adds or rules out a certain “look” that has been drawn onto the character. Once you figure what things are associated with, you’re fine. It’s also randomly generated, so you can get some pretty ridiculous combinations.


TL;DR : It’s more fun than it may seem, weirdly addictive, easy to get used to and a fun time killer. I’d say to try it. It’s cheap, why not?

Unlike the previous negative reviews, I'm gonna explain a bit in depth why I don't feel this is up to par for Edmund's standard.

Fingered is more or less a police line sim where you pick whodunit and based on the clues you'll either be wrong or right.

While some clues initially do seem hard to recognise (he looks ugly/messy/dumb/hippy/fat/goth/gay/like a bear/etc), the visual clues actually are very similar.  That being said, I feel it's unfair for people to point this out as being impossible to notice; as once you do, you will always nail that visual clue down.  I actually find it hard not to make it to day 10+, where the game does start to become difficult.

Looking messy will always have that person having disheveled hair, or a snotty nostril; for example.  Once you get that down, the curveballs are what will usually get you.  A good example is on one of the later days, a character speaks almost in gibberish for the clues.

Unfortunately, Papers Please has done this type of game far better than this in terms of not only visual but textual clues; and as a game as a whole.  It's not a bad game, but considering who made it, (Binding of Isaac and Super Meat Boy!) it's quite disappointing; even despite its low price tag.

MANUAL STIMULATION JOKE!
Indeed.  Now that I've fulfilled the bargain I've made with the entity representing the platonic ideal of childish gutter humor, let's talk about Fingered.

Ever play that board game, Guess Who?  Of course you have.  Just open up your mental filing cabinet, flip past all the childhood trauma that's made you the lovable misanthropic troglodyte you are today (just me?), and find the spot you put all the things that happened but have had as much impact on your development as a fruit fly's flaccid anatomy brushing past your ear.  Look next to the troll dolls, subsection: gradeschool recess rainouts.  Trust me, that's when you played Guess Who.

If for some reason, you never played Guess Who and were greatly affected by troll dolls:

1. Please don't message me, you poof-haired freak.

2. You weren't missing much.  Guess Who is a formalized version of 20 questions, where you and an opponent have a gallery of charicatures and you each have to deduce a specific portrait from the lineup by asking yes or no questions of your opponent to narrow down the pool.

Anyway, Fingered is the computer version of that except you're playing against an opponent that is somehow even more unreliable than a five year-old you.

So why am I still giving Fingered my best Fonzie hands?  Well, the whole game has a grimy surrealism about it, like a drunk hobo telling you about the time he was abducted by aliens.  It's totally unreliable, and near impossible to make out any truth that might be in there, but entertaining all the same.

Unreliability is an important concept to Fingered.  See, the hint-givers in Fingered treat the game as fairly as I treat troll doll aficionados.  Some of their statments will be absolutely true, others only possibly true, some hints can never be repeated, and some are delivered by means of putting the English language through a blender and just passing you whatever tasty looking chitlins the witness gloms onto.

Combine these and other logical peculiarities with the weird art style you'll recognize from The Binding of Isaac and you'll find fingering others is a challenging but pleasurable experience.  (And now my dark pact is complete)

So why did I almost thumb this one down?

Yes, yes I did so almost throw Fingered into the deep, dark hole with the others.  (That's a bonus manual stimulation joke for those of you keeping score at home)

Because it's a short and very simple game that could've been a flash game?  No.  Those are points in its favor as far as I'm concerned.  It's a good game to play when you need to kill ten minutes.  It's like Minesweeper but visually interesting.  And that's why it gets more cred than a flash game.  That and its macabre humor is enough to keep me smiling so that I feel it's earned its two bucks.  I mean, come on.  You have power of life and death over a bunch of troll-doll looking wierdos dependent upon your mad Guess Who cred.

No.  What makes me want to thumb this down is how broken and rushed the game feels.  Almost all of the levels can be solved once you figure out what statements apply to which randomly generated portrait features.  However, I've had moments where clearly bald people were the guilty party when given not bald" as a reliable clue

Now that I finally 100%'d it, yeah this game is amazing! It's got so much variation, so it stays interesting every playthrough. I thoroughly enjoyed it!

Many others have expressed their dislike of the style of game, they felt the hints were too archaic, the game too repetitive. Those people all have under an hour played..... If a witness comes in and describes a suspect the exact same way as a different witness, then where does human individuality come into play? Fingered plots you in a position where you've gotta identify subjective descriptions, and differentiate between strict, disambiguous opinions and those that make you think about whose family you're about to ruin.

Fingered is a solid game! It's not Super Meat Boy, it's not Isaac, it's just Fingered. It's fun, immersive, quirky, difficult, hilarious, and well worth the money.

reviewText:
Basically Republican Governor Simulator 2015, except for gameplay reasons there are negative consequences to executing people. Each day (there are 21 in all) you will be presented with a witness to a crime that will give a few clues to the criminal they saw and you have to deduce which of those present in the lineout is the one they mean. At which point you finger them and pull the lever to electrocute them, at which point it will show you the next days newspaper showing whether you go the correct guy.

Initially it seems very difficult, as the descriptions often seem overly vague - for example if you get told the criminal was ugly that seems like it doesn't help at all, as they all seem ugly. As you get the wrong guy over and over you will work out which visual clues match which descriptions however (or you can short circuit the process and use one of the guides which describes what each graphical element of the person tells you about them), and pretty soon you can zip through all the early easy days with simple clues, no time limits and few people in the lineout to the later days where things get more challenging as you try to get that perfect run of 21 sizzling criminals.

There isn't a huge amount of depth here, but it is a fun little time waster for a while once you get a grasp on the terminology used by the various witnesses.

reviewText:
Simple and entertaining. The art is hilarious and the music really puts you in the mood to finger.
-----
It's not a difficult game once you get the hang of it. What I mean is that the more you play, the more you realize what each word means. For example, odd could mean not human or furry means hairy. This all depends on who is the witness. After getting the hang of those types of clues and paying attention to the suspect details = easy.

With each day (or level), the game does get harder, which surprises me! I did not think that it would get much harder. James and Ed did a really good job at making it harder by using different mechanics. It keeps it fresh for new players.

Unfortunately, there is hardly a menu. You can't change the volume and you can't make it full screen. All you can do other than play the game is just type in names to see their mug shot profile.

For a game less than $5, it is worth it. Entertaining for a short amount of time. REALLY casual. Does not beat any of Ed's other games but does a good job of entertaining me with what it is. If you have some pocket change to spare, I suggest giving it a go. 21 levels of oddity and fun stereotypical jokes.
-----
It's a joke altogether. If you are expecting a game that will last you thousands of gameplay hours, you're looking at the wrong game. It's a cheap game that has its gimmicks, which entertains for a short amount of time.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The game is very interesting to boot however it has many flaws that is keeping it from having that badge of Edmund greatness to it.

cons:

Guess Edmund really didn’t care that much to properly program conflicting situations and clothing in the game.

-The art sometimes is so janky you can not possibly tell what you are looking for.

pros:
-If you like the board game Guess Who then you will like this game for about five minutes out of the day.

Sure the game is cheap however that does not exclude it from having major flaws and abandonment of options. The game just seem so alien to the Edmund’s charm and quality we’re used to.

The game get’s repetitive which brings the replay value down monumentally, it is a silly game indeed but not a must have. If you see it for twenty cents on sale then pick it up if you are curious or would like a chuckle.

reviewText:
Well...

As a big fan of McMillen's work so far this 2 Euro title was a no-brainer to me and I was really happy to have it considering it offers a totally well-made humorous approach to the whodunnit genre.

Why don't I recommend it?
The reasons are quite simple: The game has a bug that doesn't allow me to play it fullscreen but crashes when I alt-tab. Still, I'm glad that I don't suffer from the loading screen crash bug that other players experience (although there's a manual workaround). You might wonder why I alt-tab anyways... because the game has NO OPTIONS to change anything. Another big downside deriving from that is the lack of a music on/off switch. This is a big minus to me, because it -being a windowed game- has to be muted in the mixer of Win if you want to listen to music, watch something or play a match of Hearthstone on the side.
The gameplay itself has the typical McMillen style we all love so much but lacks of variety. Fingering suspects gets repetitive quickly and if you know the witness characters, finding the guilty is not that hard anymore, so the game has no real challenges.

I will still fire this up from time to time to see if there will be stuff added/fixed, but I doubt it. I hope Mew-Genics won't be that disappointing. The Super Meat Boy/the Binding of Isaac fanboy in me made a mistake, for the next titles I will check let'splays first, which I strongly recommend to everyone.

An optimistic 5/10

reviewText:
If it cost more than it did, I don't think this game could get away with what it does. Fingered has simple gameplay with easy controls and a great deal of visual personality, but will be overstaying its welcome by the time you're a skilled enough detective to actually finish the game.

The frequent comparison Fingered gets is to Guess Who, and that's certainly apt, but I found that as I chased down all of the achievements it started to also feel a bit like a contemporary roguelite. Similar to how you can luck into a powerful item combination in Binding of Isaac, in Fingered, luck can determine if you have clear and useful clues and visually distinct suspects, or if you're left guessing between similar candidates and hoping for the best. In theory, every set of clues is complete enough to pick out the exact candidate, but the random element is always a factor.

Completing the game requires a thorough understanding of its visual vocabulary- for example, being able to distinguish between goths, punks, and hipsters, or knowing whether a pair of glasses is smart or just stylish, or when a beard is full enough to count as scruffy. Developing this kind of deep understanding of often arbitrary rules of categorization runs the risk of making the simple, early stages tedious to repeatedly navigate for a chance at the more difficult later stages. The single music track can also be grating on the ears. Between these two factors, the game felt kind of irritating to pursue to 100% completion. (At the same time, 100% completion is accessible enough that I still felt compelled to go for it, so I guess it wasn't SO bad...)

But Fingered still offers a fairly unique puzzle experience, and enough of a challenge to make an ultimate victory feel rewarding. And it costs less than two shiny american dollars, so it's easy to overlook the lack of bells and whistles (and volume/music options). And if you're a fan of Edmund McMillen's previous games, it's definitely worth a look, even if the gameplay is a big step away from standard fare.

reviewText:
Firstly, go in inspecting a flash game that may last you a couple hours, maybe more if you really enjoy it. I used the small balance I have from steam cards, meaning I didn't really pay for this either, even then the price point is quite low.

If your expectations are a highly replayable extremely polished game, then you will be let down.

So, what is this game? It's a game full of ridiculous art, and it's a guess who game. You are briefly told about any quirks a witness may have, then given four clues to try and narrow down who comitted the crime. There are 21 levels, and the clues and the culprits are randomly generated. The witness is the same on each round (slightly less replayable because of it). If you are in to the indie scene, you may see some familiar faces as well :). This is all the core gameplay is.

There is one other piece of the game that is good for a quick laugh. Essentially, you just type in your name (or anyone elses), and it will generate a mug shot, along with some facts about this person. It's mildly entertaining for a few minutes.

If you're expecting any more than what I described for your money, then you will be let down. If you go in with these expectations, you should find it quite enjoyable!
